oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Oxen led to water
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An African American farmer leads a team of yoked oxen to the water's edge. Seven seemingly amused women sit on the wagon bed. A small crude building is in the background.

Oxen often were used as heavy work animals in the 19th century South. They supplied much of the power associated with agriculture and loading and unloading cargo-laden steamboats. Oxen hauled heavy loads, plowed fields, and removed stumps and rocks.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Earl S. Miers River Photograph Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cattle; Carts & wagons; Ox teams; Women; African Americans; Bodies of water
